title: Political campaigns are too long, as Iowa knows well. Here's a remedy.
text:
CLOSE Democrat Steve Bullock, the sitting governor of Montana, spoke Thursday, Aug. 8, 2019, at the Des Moines Register Political Soapbox at the Iowa State Fair. Des Moines Register, Des Moines Register

In Iowa we will be hosting 2024 presidential candidates by December 2020. Here's one way to end the never-ending campaigns that fuel our divisions.

DES MOINES, Iowa — Someone asked me the other day how soon potential 2024 presidential candidates would start showing up in Iowa after next year’s election. The depressing answer, based on recent election cycles, is as early as November or December 2020.

Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida was the first 2016 candidate to set foot in Iowa after the 2012 election. He headlined a fundraiser just weeks after Election Day for then-Gov. Terry Branstad. In December 2016, at least one Democrat considered a potential 2020 presidential candidate attended a progressive interest-group event in Iowa. President-elect Donald Trump and Veep-elect Mike Pence showed up in Iowa for a “thank you” tour that same month.

Iowans, whose caucuses launch the national presidential primary season every four years, aren’t alone in experiencing the perpetual campaign. Trump filed for reelection the day he took office and raised millions during his first year. It was one of the first of many departures from common practice: Barack Obama did not file for reelection until he had served two years in office.

Long campaigns feed gridlock

Voters and elected officials alike complain about the never-ending campaign, but we rarely hear anyone proposing to do something specific about it. After all, it benefits incumbents to pad their reelection bankroll before any challenger even thinks about running.

The length of the campaign also feeds into the hyperpartisanship and gridlock we see in Congress and the overwhelming power of special interest donors. That’s one of the main reasons Democratic presidential candidate Steve Bullock, the governor of Montana, is proposing a rule that federal elected officials must spend half of their terms actually governing.

Montana Gov. Steve Bullock campaigns for the Democratic presidential nomination on Sept. 21, 2019, in Des Moines, Iowa. (Photo: Brian Powers/Des Moines Register)

In a plan Bullock unveiled last week, the president and members of the House and Senate would have to close their campaign fundraising accounts after each election, and they would be prohibited from raising campaign money for half of their terms.

Bullock, now in his second term, argues that elected officials don’t have time to govern because they have to spend an average of four hours every day on the phone, raising money. “That time could actually be used attending committee hearings and floor sessions, which far too many of our elected members don’t do,” he said. “That time could be spent listening to concerns of constituents or … heaven forbid, building relationships with members of Congress, even members of the opposing party.”

More time for pols to do their jobs

Bullock's approach is relatively simple: Require all candidates, win or lose, to close their campaign accounts after the election. Any money left after debts are paid could not be transferred to a new campaign committee. It instead would have to be either refunded or donated to charity or the presidential matching funds program. Or — get this — the money could be donated to the government for the purposes of deficit reduction. (Snort.)

The idea wouldn’t stop would-be presidential candidates from showing up in Iowa years before the caucuses. They can always open their own issue-advocacy committees for travel to places like Iowa, or write a book and come here on tour. But it's likely to encourage elected officials to spend more of their time actually doing their jobs. And maybe we'd have to see fewer campaign ads on TV.

Gov. Bullock: I can win back the states Donald Trump took

The restrictions would also apply to challengers. The proposal would also prevent something that could be a more personal grudge for Bullock. Federal officials could not transfer campaign money for their current office into a campaign for another federal office, as many of Bullock’s opponents for the Democratic presidential nomination have been able to do. You can read more details on Bullock's campaign website,

Bullock is among Democratic candidates who have proposed efforts to reverse the effects of the Citizens United ruling that allowed corporate campaign donations. He said that’s also important, and he also wants to shine more light on “dark money” that benefits campaigns. But this plan would theoretically be easier than amending the Constitution and, he argued, might actually come as a relief to many lawmakers.

Candidates are here, put them on spot

Bullock counters skepticism that lawmakers would agree to tie their own hands like this. He said some former U.S. senators, asked how they’d like it if they couldn’t raise money for the first few years in office, told him: “Boy, that would change my ability to do my job.”

Fundraising, apparently, isn’t a favorite part of Bullock’s job as a presidential candidate. “Any candidate that just absolutely loves that should probably be unpacking that psychological suitcase right there,” he said with a laugh.

Patriotism contest: Take back the flag, 2020 Democrats. 'Liberty and justice for all' is a patriotic value.

The proposal comes at a time when Iowa voters can take advantage of their access to candidates. On behalf of the nation, we can press them to commit to closing their campaign committees for the first half of their terms. Because if we think it serves us to have our elected officials spending more time raising money than doing their job, we should be unpacking that psychological suitcase, too.

Kathie Obradovich is the Opinion editor for the Des Moines Register, where this column first appeared. Follow her on Twitter: @KObradovich
